prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ebonite feed heat‑set". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Ebonite Feed-Set

Twas splenlightime, and charcoogleams  
Did shimmer ’mid the bramblevais;  
All britch and bright with feedlet-beams,  
And heat-set’s steamy haze.  

“Beware the feedwump, my borowling dear,  
The heat-set that hisses in gloom!”  
Beware the ebonite feedwump, I fear!  
And shun its ember-toom.  

He seized his gleaming feedspade then,  
Long sought he the feedwump at eve;  
So rested he by the smolderfen,  
And vowed he would not leave.  

And, as in murk of nightshade gloam,  
The feedwump with viffling sighs  
Came whiffling through the smokefold dome,  
And glowed with embered eyes.  

“One, two! One, two! Snick-snack!” he dealt  
The feedwump a final blow;  
He left it still, its terror quelled,  
In ashes faintly aglow.  

Then hastened he through heat-set trails,  
With ebonite prize in hand;  
He sang of wroth and triumph tales,  
And warmed the flickering land.  

“O blessèd feed-set, O ebonite gleam!  
No feedwump shall dare return;  
Our heaps of hearth with joy redeem,  
And ember-lights shall burn!”

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Hollow-Grind O1 Ode

’Twas blenzled in the forgesque night,  
The O1 blade did shimmerbright;  
All slinkish smiths with hammers clang  
Did grumble-grind its hollow fang.

“Beware the Grimbled Hollow’s edge,  
The bevel’d bane of sharpened dread;  
Beware the lurk of burr and nick,  
And shankle-shine that dulls too quick!”

He took his strop-staff in his hand;  
Long time he sought the whetstone land.  
And as he spurred his leather-bound,  
He heard a wheeze—grim hollow sound!

One, two! One, two! With stinging gleam  
He honed the blade—a steely dream!  
He left it honed, all wav’ring-sheened,  
And homeward strode ’mid whispering sheen.

“O hollow-grind, O O1 blade,  
Thy edge in sparklings never fade!  
Through muck and mire, through slake and stain,  
Thy keen delight shall e’er remain.”

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "forged leaf scroll". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Forged Leaf Scroll

Twas woodmorn and the splintering gloam,  
When woodgleaves quivered in dewblink storms;  
All bramblefronds heaved with hushful gloom,  
And the timberkin sighed its oldform norms.

Beware the Forged Leaf Scroll, my dear,  
A goldbent scripture of rootcursed dread;  
Beware its thornruned whispers near,  
And the vinespire’s beckon through gloam so spread.

He seized his briarblade keen and bright,  
And trod the mosspath ’neath starlace skies;  
Long time he hunted the runebound blight,  
Till oakshadows pulsed where the scroll lies disguised.

Then sprang the glyphfire from writhen seal;  
The scrollflame hissed with barkshard hail;  
He parried leafbites with valeward zeal,  
And cleft the runes from the dreadgrove’s jail.

“Scrollfold off! Scrollfold off!” he cried,  
As dewdusk stole the scroll’s hemic power;  
The wood’s heart eased, the gnarlbeasts sighed,  
Their fetter-wicks freed in the twilight hour.

O bramblefree dawn! O woodlore bright!  
He bore the rentrune to hearth’s warm glow;  
And bards retell his fearless fight,  
Yet whisper—dreadlore only seeds woe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiln witness cone bend". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Kilnwock Witness

’Twas scorchly, and the crumflit brims  
Did shiver on the ember-beds;  
All beamish sparks and coiléd limbs  
Did froth beneath the glowing reds.

Beware the Kilnwock, my dear,  
The bendcap’s twist and searéd maw;  
Beware the braxly cone-bend sneer,  
And dread its glowing, cratered jaw.

He grasped his fender-spade in hand;  
Long time he trod the furnace glade;  
He watched the kiln-bolts crack and stand,  
And scanned the cone where shadows fade.

And as the Kilnwock warbled keen,  
He heaved his blade in braxton swing;  
He crushed the cone-bend furnace keen,  
And bore the witness of the thing.

poem:
The Frabjous Composing Stick

Twas the slubbergnome in Printfield sligh,  
All the scrivey-scribes did quake;  
They clamped their quivering jaws at night  
As the type began to wake.  

Beware the lead type in the composing stick,  
The kerplunk and clatter-slick!  
Beware the spittlewomp and fribbly fonts,  
And the jumble-scrunch so thick!  

He seized his jawsome quoin with care,  
And whiffling-sorted row by row;  
He clacked the rack, he clamped the pair,  
Then watched the letters glow.  

And as the frabjous dawn drew nigh,  
The text flew forth in flight:  
A brillig ballet across the sky,  
With words in gleeful light.  

O frabjous day! The print was wrought!  
The lines did shimmer free!  
In Printfield’s press the boon was caught:  
Lead type’s bright jubilee!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "urushi lacquer cure". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Urushi Lacquer Cure

Twas the minging glow of night,  
And shin-blot branches whirr;  
All flecked the lacquer’s shimmer-bright,  
And spouted japan’s burr.  

“Beware the Urushi Cure, my dear!  
The glossy stain, the venom’d gore!  
Beware its gloss and slick frontier,  
And shun the lacquer’d shore!”  

He took his bristle-blade in hand;  
Long time the shin-flecked woods he wrought,  
Then rested by a murk-filled strand  
And pondered cunning thought.  

And as in noon’s tremor’d glare  
The Urushi Cure, with claws of sheen,  
Came whiffling through the lurid air  
And glimmer’d fierce and keen.  
One, two! One, two! And through and through  
His bristle-blade went snick-snack clean!  

He left it dead, as gloss life fled,  
And bore its lacquer’d head.  
O beamish boy! The Cure is dead!  
The woods rejoice instead.  

O frabjous day! The stain is cur’d!  
The japans spark with light.  
The gnarled dread of gloss, abjur’d,  
No more to haunt the night.  

But mark my words, young lacquer-lover:  
Though Cure be slain with blade so small,  
Its gleaming fumes may hover,  
And stain the weakest wall.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plum brown blueing bath". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Plum-Brown Blueing Bath

’Twas the gloam of the plum-brown blueing bath,  
When the slurple gloogs did fringle and frass;  
All snug were the snivels in foaming path—  
Beware the blithy scrith with its girshing gasp!

He took his glimblade in warling hand,  
Long time he brangled the stubborn foam;  
But down from the brim of the fizzled strand  
The blithy scrith did swirl and roam.

One, two! One, two! Through the plum-brown wave  
He slashed with a roar and a sworpling ring;  
And out from the churn of the blueing nave  
The scrith fell hush’d with a broken wing.

O frabjous joy! He danced in the gleam,  
His glimblade gleamed with victor’s light;  
And the gloogs all sang by the rippling stream  
In the plum-brown blueing bath that night.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "farewell at a platform". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Farewell at a Platform

Twas gloamish by the plat-crown pier,  
The screech-gasms wheezed and roared,  
All trundle-moths and shimmer-sneer  
Did flicker ’cross the board.  
“Beware the brake-bomb’s blur and clang,  
The shiver-whistle’s smear,  
The fleeting-flume of farewells rang  
And tugged at hearts so dear.”

She stood in mist of smog-wrought gleam,  
In finery brocade,  
Her eyes aflame with stormish dream,  
Her shy smile twilight-swayed.  
He clasped his battered valisac,  
A hollow sigh and knell;  
He cried, “Adieu, my heartsnug dear,  
Till moon-time finds us well.”

The carriage hissed its murmur-snort,  
Its chime-sprockets did hum;  
The clutch-leap, footboard’s rattle-thump,  
And wistful-bells did drum.  
She waved once more—her gleam-bow sighed,  
Her mistle-cheeks aglow;  
Her tender voice, a tremble-wind:  
“Go soft, my fond must-go.”

So off he sped through murk and blaze,  
Through rattle-churn and gloom;  
Yet in each clack of wheel-echoed haze  
He felt her silken plume.  
For parting on that plat-gloom floor  
Had twined their fates so warm,  
And every steam-snort roared once more  
The promise of reform.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ink brayer and chase". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Inkbrayer’s Chase

’Twas brimlorn and the inkworms flushed,  
The folio grove with murk did swell;  
All scribble-knights with quillheads gnashed,  
Yet felt the gloom of blot-star fell.  

“Beware the Inkbrayer—spraffle-spill!  
The gloomp it weaves on vellum’s face!  
Its glimmer-globs o’er pages trill  
To throttle lines in splotch and lace!”  

They seized their nibhorns, penblades bright,  
And launched the chase by moonlit span;  
Through mottleweed and flittered night,  
They sought to foil the ink-borne ban.  

The Inkbrayer roared with squelch and bray,  
Its splodge-spear flung in flaring arcs;  
The tibber-tide of inky fray  
Did churn and drench those gallant bards.  

At dawn they pinned the beast in paste,  
Its gloopy reign at last put down;  
But quills still quake for whispered trace  
Of future hunts in scriptorium town.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "summit prayer flag". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Summit Prayer Flag

Twas the breezing time at crumplecrest,  
And the wind-skirled peaks did sway;  
All flimbered the glint-gold prayer-flags,  
In dawn’s soft shimmer-gray.  

“Beware the stormblight, my mountain-folk!  
The thunder-krait’s fierce breath;  
Beware the hailquake’s rattling roar,  
And snow-sleet’s shatter-death!”  

He grasped his gossamer-wrought pennon,  
With vows of hope and grace;  
And upward through the snowlorn crags  
He strode with steady pace.  

The stormblight roared with crash and scream,  
Its shadowed talons scraped;  
Yet prayer-flags twirled their rainbow hymns  
Across the frostedcape.  

O frabjous dawn! the heavens cleared,  
The summit’s hush unfurled;  
And every fluttering prayer-flag  
Sent peace into the world.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "luthier's soundpost setter". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Soundpost Setter

’Twas timbresnug, and the fiddle-bloom  
Did shimmer and drane in the case;  
All pegknops dozed in perfumed gloom,  
And the scroll-sprig sighed apace.

He seized his wimbrel, sprightly and slim,  
Long-grooved tip and copper-brace;  
He slunk beneath spruce-limned dim  
To find the wobble-space.

Beware the jitter-post’s sly disgrace!  
The creak that quavers free!  
Beware the snap and sliding base,  
The stray tone’s woeful plea!

With measured press and whiffling spell,  
He eased the slender post;  
It chimed like brook through hollow dell,  
And quelled the souring ghost.

Triumphant then, he rose with pride,  
Through bowwood’s misty veil;  
The strings rejoiced on every side,  
As dawn drew sweetest tale.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "night‑blooming cereus vigil". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Night-Blooming Cereus Vigil

Twas brindlewight in gloaming grey,  
All moonfrond lay asleep;  
The cereus held its lustrous sway  
Where silver-shivers creep.  

Beware the gloamwraith’s whisperthin,  
The snagrib’s silent dart;  
For petals still at twilight’s din  
And beckon midnight’s heart.  

He bore his glowquill, lantern bright,  
Through fernmote’s dew-draped maze;  
He sought the bloom’s ghostly delight  
In starwound, quivering rays.  

At hush of hour the corollight  
Unfurled its skein of lace;  
It pulsed with lunar lullaby  
And glimmered phantom-lace.  

The spangle-sprites in filigree  
Did pirouette around;  
Yet none outshone that bloom’s decree  
Nor sacred hush profound.  

Then snap! The blossom flared agleam—  
O frabjous coruscate!  
It wove the night into a dream  
Beyond the hands of fate.  

And thus I keep this vigil still  
Till dawn’s first rosicle gleam;  
I guard the cereus’ silver thrill  
In moonstuff’s mystic seam.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "modular synth patch spaghetti". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Patch-Spaghetti

Twas wibbly, and the knobbles sprung  
Through cables tangle-snatched;  
All wiry in the rack they clung  
In coiled gromp and glomp attached.  

Beware the Spaghettimon, my chum!  
The morpho-ring so sly!  
Beware its spatterglitch and hum,  
And shudder at its cry!  

He grabbed his patch-cord, gleaming fine,  
Long lead of copper-sheen;  
And braved the boilered synthy line  
Where signals hissed between.  
He twiddled snibble, twisted slew,  
Then leapt into the gnarled crew.  

Then spat the Spaghettimon its roar,  
A glibbering, gnarled squall;  
And glops of sauce and sparks galore  
Did spurt from rack and wall.  

One, two! One, two! The loops unspun!  
Klink-klank went all around;  
He slew the tangle, one by one,  
And stilled the snarling sound.  
O spaghobulous day! The circuits paid,  
The patch at peace was found.  

He gazed upon the silent spread,  
No glitch nor hiss remained;  
Then coiled his cords beneath his head,  
His triumph unconstrained.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "cassette wow and flutter". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cassettwocky

Twas spinnage, and the slubber-speed  
Did wobble in the cassette;  
All mimsy reels on crimble-feed  
Were caught in flutter-set.  

Beware the Flutterwock, my dear!  
The dreaded Wow-and-Flutter!  
It lurks within the bias gear,  
And leaves your hearing stutter.  

He took his Bromlex blip and blade,  
Long bided in the wobbly rack;  
And as the hissing waves arrayed,  
He braved the flutter-trap.  

One twiddle more, the hero cried,  
“I’ll vanquish this audio curse!”  
The flutter-waves he turned aside,  
And drove the hiss to hearse.  

The Flutterwock gave final squeal,  
Its wow-and-flutter slain;  
Its spindles shrank to spinning zeal,  
And silence ruled the chain.  

Tum-tum trays in countdown hum,  
Did bob and coo in glow;  
Then songs of gold and memory come,  
Revived from long ago.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "opal play‑of‑color flash". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Opal Play-of-Color Flash

’Twas opalick, and the playflash gleamed,  
The glimsy whorls in prismic streams;  
All flumpled were the gem-hide chen,  
And shimmerflecks danced on the glen.  

“Beware the blandish bore of gray,  
The murkrug slurp that steals the day;  
Lest dull unfurl its vapid thrall  
And drain the blush from us all!”  

He seized his glintbar, sleek and bright,  
And prowled the night ’twixt shade and light;  
Through opaline glade and glimmering vale,  
He challenged gloom’s relentless pale.  

He parried drab with opal glare,  
Then cleft the drudgemon unaware;  
O sparkful hour! O glistering glee!  
He freed the world from all drear debris.  

Callooh for hues that dance and flash!  
Callay for play-of-color splash!  
Let prismic blooms in every sky  
Forever gleam where dreamers lie.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "peony ants at dawn". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Peony Ants at Dawn

Twas droppy-morn in the tawny glade,  
And peony ants did scramble and gleam;  
All brantly were their pomfrey-shade,  
And dewlight danced with a pastel beam.  

Beware the Bulbabeet, my tiny throng,  
With ember-pincers and quillthroat hum!  
Its frapsome roar and splintered song  
Would crumple your blooms and hush the drum.  

He seized his honeysilk prong in hand,  
And sallied through the flowery gobbering spray;  
The ants upheld their flag-bloom band,  
Their quavering cheers at the birth of day.  

Then bursting from tulgey brier and thorn,  
The Bulbabeet swooped with a hissing flare;  
It flung its fiery fangs at morn  
And spangled the air with candleglint hair.  

One, two! One, two! The prong leapt forth!  
It clove the beast with a flicker-snack!  
It tumbled down from the blossomed north,  
And the dawn sighed softly upon its back.  

And hast thou rescued the peony ants?  
Rejoice, my bloomish brood, now fey and free!  
O frabjous dawn! O petal dance!  
We chortle and bliss in the blossoming spree.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "oscilloscope lissajous bloom". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Oscilloscope Lissajous Bloom

’Twas whispish-wave, and the lissabands  
    did fringle on the board;  
All moltic beams did shimstrand,  
    and quaft the curves they stored.  

Beware the Oscilloscope Bloom, my dear!  
    The sinevex wraith that twists in gloom;  
Beware its frabulated ear  
    and frizzle-doodle’s doom!  

He took his probe in wobble-hand,  
    He coaxled each wild trace;  
Through shimmerframe and dappled land  
    He hunted every chase.  

One flick, two flick! With hum and glum  
    He snared the bloom’s last tune;  
And home he strode ’neath silver hum  
    on yonder pulse-lit moon.  

O lissabloom day! Zingoo! Zingabloom!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "civet note and drydown". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Civet’s Drydown Note

’Twas brummish eve, and haggard gloom,  
All twisthorns sigh’d in sad array;  
Beware the civet-note’s muskish doom,  
Where drydowns prance at close of day.

The breeful vapors flit and flare,  
A hum of vermedawn’s perfumed light;  
They lure the souls who faintly dare  
To chase the scent through blumble-night.

Brave Nimbleton, with snorebright blade,  
Spurn’d peptral dread and frizzy fright;  
He sought the flit of civet-scented shade  
To claim the call at dawn’s first light.

He spied the drydown’s shimmerfrost,  
A wivvering cloud of musk and dew;  
They howled, they whispear’d, they battle-toss’d,  
But Nimbleton through smogling flew.

And ere the brummish eve could sigh,  
He caught the drucken civet note;  
Now frelic glows ’neath berris sky,  
The drydowns fade at hero’s throat.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Reglet and Furnipple

Twas brillig in the borple-nook,  
All slumped the chairs with flurry crook;  
The reglet gleamed with snicker-sheen  
Amid the grand parquet routine.  

Beware the slithy furnipple!  
The jumbly leg, the knotted kipple,  
It gnaws through spines of oak and pine  
To foul your halls with screeching whine.  

He took his bradawl, swift and stout,  
And guerdled at the reglet’s bout;  
He pried 'neath joint and splintered seam,  
Till shrieg the furnipple did scream.  

O frabjous day! The chairs are whole,  
No more the knurgling ragged hole;  
The reglet keeps its trusty groove,  
And furniture may safely move.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "old piton scar". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Old Piton Scar

’Twas gnarled and grim the cliffside lair,  
With frumpled crags and shim’ry spall;  
The daring climbers heard despair  
In whispers round that brittle wall.  
Beware the ancient Piton Scar,  
The spur that slices boulders’ hearts;  
Beware its shard of whispered war  
Where stone and time hold trembling parts.  

He took his flensing pick in hand,  
And strode beneath the jutting ledge;  
The wind did snarl across the land  
And flirbled o’er the rocky edge.  
“With sturdy grip and nerve to spare,  
I’ll tame the scar of ages gone,”  
He cried, “no grim old trap shall snare  
My soul before I bring it down!”  

Up crag and flint his gaunt boots clung,  
Through splintered groves of marl and shale;  
Each breath a glimmer, old tunes sung  
By echoes in the canyon pale.  
But as he neared that fissure’s maw,  
A shrieking tremor shook the stone—  
The Piton Scar unleashed its claw  
To tear the flesh from bone alone.  

He braced his pick on crumbling lime,  
Yet shards of shadow swirled and leapt;  
A frabjous roar outpaced all time  
And froze his blood while silence wept.  
Then, with a twist and fearless heart,  
He wrenched the aged iron free—  
The scar dissolved in lightning’s part,  
Release of dread, and victory.  

Now travelers tell the brave affair  
Of how the Piton Scar was slain;  
They mind the tale when winds blow bare,  
And stick their picks in hope again.  
For every cliff and stone-bound scar  
Awaits a hand both true and bold—  
To claim the heights where legends are,  
And carve new songs from tales of old.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "loom shuttle pick". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Loom-Shuttle Pick

Twas glimy, and the linty looms  
Did spangle and shudder through the glooms;  
All picksy were the shuttles stark,  
And quiverwands did whirr and spark.  

Beware the Loom-Shuttle Pick, my son!  
Its warpish claws, its fleecy run!  
Beware the Loom-Shuttle Pick—  
Its silken flick, its warpish trick!  

He seized his trusty shuttle-stick  
And strode along the warpwood thick;  
All twistim through the loomish dell  
Where glared the Pick’s unbridled spell.  

One twang! The shuttle-stick did slash;  
He smote the Pick with bracken-gash.  
And hast thou slain the Loom-Shuttle Pick?  
O frabjous day! O warpish trick!  

The looms now ring with fizz and hum,  
Triumphed the Weaver, foe now numb;  
She weaves anew with joyous glee,  
All hail the Weaver’s victory!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "tinsmith stake song". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Tinsmith’s Stake-Song

’Twas the glinting gloam of the tinnish eve,  
When stakesnip tangles and clankers weave;  
The tinsmiths’ hammers whimbled their flakes,  
While sparkled the bars of briddle-stakes.  

Far in the brumish glade it lay,  
The stakebeast snuffling a steamy fray;  
Its flint-slice eyes gave a huffsnort croon  
As it gnash-snickered beneath twin moons.  

Armed with a scraw of scrithing steel,  
The tinsmith strode through the tangle-weal;  
He chirred, “Hoot the stake-grin from fang to flank!”  
Then dance-slashed his blade in a shimmy-swank.  

One thwack! and the stakebeast chirked a glark,  
Two wham! and it sank in the gnarled mark;  
The tinsmith gleamed with a fizzle-flash grin,  
As stake-suss waned in the whimsy-bin.  

O sing the song of the tinsmith’s feat,  
Where metal hearts beat a clamor-sweet;  
Let bar-gleams ring till dawn’s first spark  
And hush the echoes of the stakebeast’s bark.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pietra dura inlay". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Pietra-Dura Dream

Twas glimmerish eve in marblous grove,  
When tessellune shards did gleam;  
The pietra-dura inlay wove  
A gemmy-symphonix dream.  

Bewildered, sculptor Marbelle  
With raspéd hand did glide;  
She spattled hues of onyx-swell  
In cove of carven tide.  

The swirléd pattern pulsed and glowed  
In fractal-brilliance broad;  
While polisher’s touch bestowed  
A sheen with glossolode nod.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blue hour on snow". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Blue Hour on Snow

’Twas bluenipped in the snow-frazzle hour,  
When glimmerdew danced on the lea;  
All whispermild in hush’s power,  
And winterjoy lulled the tree.  

Beware the shiverwraith’s gleamless fang,  
The glareshade creeping ’neath each bough;  
Beware its mockmirth, a frosty sang,  
And the chillgleam on your brow.  

I drew my gleamsabre with heart alight,  
Through driftthick shimmer I strode;  
I met the shiverwraith in moonwhite sight,  
And I quelled its bitter ode.  

Then jubilant rose the frostdream throng,  
As blue-sheen reclaimed the sky;  
O bluenipped hour, though fleeting and long,  
Your wonder we cannot deny!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "crosstie creosote scent". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Crosstie Creosote Scent

’Twas quorpled night in railyard bent,  
The crosstie creosote scent did glimmer;  
All skirmish sparks with hiss were sent,  
To wake the bristle-brained Skimmer.  

Beware the Skimmer, breath afume,  
With luggard limbs and embered eye;  
He skulks where dormant embers fume,  
To drag the rail-folk to their sigh.  

Our hero seized his flame-spike blade,  
Its steam-born gleam a splendiferous sight;  
The Skimmer shrieked—a curlish raid—  
Then twinkled off in ragged night.  

Now safe the tracks and mosses laced,  
No more the Skimmer’s call shall rend;  
And fragrant through the gloom is traced  
The crosstie creosote scent, our friend.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "balance spring collet". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Balancespring Collet

’Twas the matrix-blink of morn’s first light,  
And the zephyr’s snifter did flost and prawn;  
All gimble-glee were the watchworks tight,  
’Neath the balancespring collet’s yawn.  

“Beware the collet, O horowhirl’s bane!  
The tickle-torque of its whirring maw!  
Beware the sproing that drives you insane,  
And the gearling’s jiggle that sets time to thaw!”  

He took his ratchet-spark and wrench-spark too,  
And tiptoed through the cog-sprung glen;  
He sought the coils that wildly flew,  
Where pendulous tick-tocks roamed in yen.  

At last he found the coil-bearer there,  
Its spring-fold flapped in a fervid dance;  
With clank and clamor of ironware,  
He seized the beast with a daring glance.  

One mighty twist, one boisterous wrench—  
The balancespring collet yielded its frill;  
All hush fell soft ’neath the gear-cat’s stench,  
As harmony filled each ticking sill.  

O joy! rejoice, ye watchmakers all,  
Let pinions gleam and pivots spin free;  
The Balancespring Collet bows its thrall,  
And time marches on in sweet unity.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pantograph arcing blue". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Pantograph Arcing Blue

Twas glimmaws, and the drimsy tracks  
Did shnibble, flume, and shimmer through;  
All wires wheezed with crackle-sacks,  
By pantograph arcing blue.  

Beware the Gloomp with farnock breath,  
The crisping sparks that slither low:  
Beware the frizzle-gnash of death,  
And spatterglow’s fierce show.  

He took his Spangle-wrench in hand,  
Mounted the iron steed with might;  
He clomb the catenary’s strand,  
By pantograph arcing blue.  

One two! One two! His wrench did crack—  
The Gloomp fell back with piteous yowl;  
He snatched its heart of sparking black,  
And quelled the gods’ rogue growl.  

Then all the lines now hum anew,  
In circuits white and cobalt hue;  
O hail the joys that power imbue,  
By pantograph arcing blue.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration Over Stubble

Twas scrimble-light ’cross the stubble-field,  
And the glimmer-straw did glow;  
The murmurich flocks in flutter’d yield  
Gleamed above the fur below.  

Beware the spickle’s whirling cry!  
The sloorish dive so sharp!  
Beware the murmuration nigh—  
Their wings the twilight warp!  

He grasped his bramble-sheathéd rod,  
Telgrin in hand he stood;  
He watched the feathery gossamer squad  
Spin dreams o’er shadowed wood.  

Oh, how the dappled murmurs swept  
O’er brittle stalks so sere!  
They twindled where hushed dew-pearl crept,  
And dawn drew softly near.  

O frabjous sight! O plume-swept throng!  
In ruddling flight so keen,  
The stubble echoed their shimmering song—  
A living, breathing sheen!  

Callooh! Callay! Let stubble ring  
With murmuration’s might;  
For wingèd chords of azure sing  
Beyond the edge of night!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pewter inlay ribbon". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Pewter-Inlay Ribbon

’Twas gleaming eve in quivverglade,  
The pewter-inlay ribbon shone;  
All glimthrush pipes in shadow played,  
While mizzle-twigs in murk did drone.  

Beware the Pewterwock, my child,  
The Ribbonwyrm with gleamy spine!  
Beware the Inlaywight so wild,  
That warps the moon with curling twine.  

He seized his silver-shear, so bright,  
And scoured the briar-bound path;  
Through duskworn coppice, dim of sight,  
He traced the ribbon’s gleaming wrath.  

And, as the quivering ribbon curled,  
The skewbry ferns began to sigh;  
Its twisted coils around him whirled,  
And whispered secrets none knew why.  

One snicker-snack! His silver blade  
Sliced through the metallic lace;  
The Ribbonwyrm in ruin laid,  
Its glist’ring coils undone in space.  

The forest hushed in argent hush,  
The pewter traces dimmed to grey;  
He paused beneath the dawn’s soft blush,  
Then turned his steps to homeward way.  

With pewter shards and ribbon-tie,  
He hailed his triumph in a dream;  
And every morn at sun’s first sigh,  
He seeks the glint of quivver-stream.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "linocut brayer chatter". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Linocut Brayer Chatter

Twas the snorfing gloam, when linocut brayer chatter  
Did clatter and clump through the laden den;  
All lino-beasts in their inky matter  
Lay hush within that printwood glen.  

Beware, O printer, the fleering brash,  
The flibber-frabber that skitters your bloom;  
Beware the blok’n’bray and its inkly slash,  
The sniggle-vex that haunts the loom.  

He seized his brayer with bristled might,  
He strode to the lino in malkin’s gloom;  
He sought to quell that maddish sprite,  
Whose squirrel-prank marred each printed bloom.  

One swirl, two press—O frabjous relief!  
He quelled the chitter with stately sweep;  
The lino sighed and all ink turned brief,  
As chatter-foul sank into sleep.  

And so from dusk till dawn’s soft light,  
No meerkling mischief marred the press;  
All prints stood proud in morning bright,  
Freed from linocut brayer chatter’s mess.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quarter‑sawn shimmer". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Quarter-Sawn Shimmer

Twas quarried morn, and saw-logs gleamed  
With quarter-sawn shimmer bright;  
The chip-tops hopped, the beaver-streamed  
Their blythewood arcs of light.  

“Beware the Shimmerjowl, my son!  
The wavering grain that lurches sly!  
Beware its fanglike lace, and shun  
Its echo in the dry!”  

He grabbed his glint-axe, sharp and true,  
And plunged where rafters loom;  
He sawed the shimmer in twain, slew  
Its hiss and phantom plume.  

Five hours he toiled ’mid splintered beams  
Till dawn’s first fable aired;  
The shimmer bowed to steady schemes,  
Its rings no more ensnared.  

He flung the glitter to the wind,  
Where woodwisp fair did dance;  
And timber hearts were freed, unpinned,  
By craft and kindly chance.  

Then home he trod through piney glen,  
His burden light as dew;  
The quarter-sawn shimmer rose again  
In wonders bright and new.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Blued Screw

 ’Twas glimmerfraught in the ruchling of dawn,  
The timberdrum’s song through the hoveling rang,  
When slitherspun from the workshop was drawn  
A blued screw in a movement, jolly and clang.  

“Beware the blued screw in a movement, my dear,  
The twistlegrim jaws that to-night shall chew!  
Beware its whirrling spines and grindlefrap sneer,  
The snick and the snack that will cunningly brew!”  

He seized his spanner, long-gleaming and keen,  
He crept by the cogs with a shimmerquaint air;  
One turn, two turns—then the clamorous scene  
Went silent as gears slipped light in the spare.  

Triumphant he traced homeward the lane,  
Spanner aloft, screw subdued by his craft;  
And all tweedlefolk, freed from mechanical bane,  
Harmonized anew in the rumbustious draft.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "parrel bead on a gaff". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Parrel Bead on a Gaff

Twas glimful dawn on the swashing main,  
The drearish breeze did snick;  
All hardy tars in hammock-rest  
Felt the rigrack’s tick.  

Beware the Parrel-Bead, my bold mate!  
The gaff-faring fiend of yore;  
With clanker jaws and glimmer-gait,  
It grips the spar-toe core.  

It skitters up the mast so sleek,  
Its ring-rack hisses clear;  
The buoyant yardarms quail and creak  
In paralyzing fear.  

But sturdy crew with tar and flint  
Did chase the scourge away;  
One lash, one twist, one thunderous dint  
And fiendish gleam gave way.  

Now sails unfurl in brackish sun,  
Our course is free and fair;  
We sing of how the feat was done  
‘Gainst Parrel-Bead’s despair.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sourdough levain autolyse". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Levain Wabe

Twas yeasty, and the crumb-blooms quaked,  
All frabjous was the slip;  
Along the bowl the levain waked  
In gloaming’s tender dip.

“Beware the Autolyse, my baker dear!  
The slackening dough, the gloopy tide!  
Beware the osmotic sear!  
And shun its weeping side!”

He paused beside the flour-scape,  
His whisk in tremor borne;  
He dreamed of ovens’ golden gape,  
Of dawn’s fermenting morn.

From midst the gloam the Autolyse  
Emerged with slurging sigh;  
It stretched its sticky, starchy guise  
And bound the wandering ply.

One, two! One, two! He whirled the bowl—  
The levain leapt with zest!  
He folded air into the soul  
Of dough that would be blessed.

“O hail thee, crumb-rise magically!  
Thy crust of amber fine!  
I’ve slain the gloopy spectracy,  
And claim thy bake as mine.”

Twas yeasty, and the crumb-blooms gleamed,  
All frabjous was the rise;  
Now oven-borne, the loaf redeemed,  
In morning’s golden prize.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sashiko boro patch". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Sashiko Boro Stitch

Twas brillig-boro in the field,  
The sashiko silks were bright;  
All tatter-edges tried to yield  
Before the moon’s soft light.  

Beware the Stitchsnark’s twisted grin,  
It snares the fray with sin;  
Its bobbin-fangs where flaws begin,  
And weaving’s law grows thin.  

He took his sashiko lance in hand,  
A needle keen and bright;  
He sought where scraps in chaos spanned  
Through ragged gloam of night.  

The Stitchsnark roared its bobbin-crave,  
Its loops both fierce and bold;  
But mender’s hand, supremely brave,  
Bound chaos in his hold.  

From faded scraps and denim scapes,  
He wove his quiet charm;  
With sashiko runs and tidelines’ tapes,  
He lulled the storm to calm.  

O menders hear this merry song,  
Of boro spirits caught;  
Where patch and thread to hearts belong,  
And fray’s lament forgot.  

The Sashiko Boro Stitch holds fast  
In seams of yesteryear;  
May its bright solace ever last  
For wardrobes far and near.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nixie tube warm glow". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Nixie’s Warm Glow

’Twas the gloaming of duskwave,  
And the nixie-tubes did shimmer;  
All flimflame danced and swayed,  
A sweetly buzzing glimmer.  

Beware the cyclobrede beam,  
The ghostled digits phlitter!  
Beware the boron vapor’s gleam,  
And the buzzing neon fritter!  

He grasped his fluxrod solder-shaft,  
Long time the glow to haft;  
So rested he by chassis’ raft  
And mused on sparking craft.  

And, as in filament-glare he dreamed,  
The nixie-numerals gleamed:  
One tube, two tube, three! They beamed,  
In amber haze redeemed.  

One spark, two spark! Through rack and flame  
He struck with neon-glow wand;  
He watched the tubes, untamed, untame,  
In flickerflame’s command.  

Then homeward sang the lumidance  
With warmish digits woven;  
And, O! the frabjous radiance  
Of currents gently cloven.  

O nixie-glow, shine ever so!  
Callooh, callight, forever glow!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fishtail gouge sweep". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fishtail Gouge-Sweep

Twas gloaming in the kelpy deeps,  
And floofy fish in shimmered heaps  
Glimmered ‘neath the briny light,  
Bewailing fins of fearsome might.  

Beware the Fishtail Gouge-Sweep, friend!  
Its chisel jaws on brine depend,  
Beware its snicker-snack of dread,  
Its bristle spear, its ruby head!  

He took his trusty glimmer-blade  
And plunged where restless currents played;  
He whiffled round the coral shelf  
Till heart and blade were matched in self.  

One slash! One splay! The monster reeled,  
Its fishtail flung, its gouge revealed;  
He heaved it past the surge’s bound,  
And heard no more that fearsome sound.  

O frabjous day! The sea-folk sing,  
The pearly reefs in triumph ring;  
He sipped his gloam-bright foamy wine  
And danced on driftwood—brine divine.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "letter kept in a cedar box". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Letter in the Cedar Box

’Twas grimbly morn in hushful glade,  
When Fendle’s hand did quiver,  
He spied a cinder-wrought arcade  
Where cedar whispers shiver.  
Within that nook of duskful pine,  
A silken box lay barred;  
Its latches gleamed with brumpled sign,  
All secret-kept and charred.

He unbound the gilded bar,  
With frindle fingers shaky;  
Inside, a script of starlight par  
Lay folded, faint, and flaky.  
Each line did glower in shimmered ink,  
With runes of mewl and mirk;  
The letters seemed to breathe and blink,  
A living, lyric work.

“Beware the Garthly Draunger’s breath,  
That loops the moon in thorn—  
And guard the glow of silent death  
Where cries may yet be born.”  
But as he read, a humble hush  
Filled Fendle’s eager heart;  
The cedar box gave forth a lush  
Of glow that could not part.

Now cedar winds around him wind,  
In brimful, bristly bloom;  
The letter’s vow, once dark confined,  
Now casts away the gloom.  
He tucks the note ’neath heartful breast,  
Beneath the cedar’s locks—  
Its words shall guide him on his quest,  
From folly’s tangled docks.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "Morse straight key click". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Morse-Straight Key Click

'Twas glintlight in the cavershade,  
When whisper-wires began to braid;  
All ’neath the jangle-junkyard gloom,  
The air was rife with echoing boom.  

Down the holler-slimed byway snick,  
The dreaded Clickerwump did stick;  
His schivver-whiskers twitched to tick,  
At every Morse straight key click.  

“Beware the quaver-snatch and whine,  
The flitter-flax of bramble-line!”  
The elder-coders hollered thus,  
Then scurried off in pandipus.  

But bold Our Hero, code in hand,  
Into the clickic hollow planned;  
He tapped a dot, he tapped a dash,  
With steadfast nerve and steady lash.  

The Clickerwump, in clatter-speak,  
Ripped forth a bellow-snatch so bleak;  
But Hero’s taps rang clear and true,  
Through hiss and fray and screeching slew.  

He clapped his hand with rapture-peal,  
The Clickerwump lay still and real;  
Then homeward through the bramble-ditch,  
He hummed the hum of clacky switch.  

O sing, ye coders far and near,  
Of Morse-straight key’s sweet frontier;  
In clicky-chord and clackish tune,  
It bridges dark to shining noon.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fiddle rosin dust". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Fiddle Rosin Dust

’Twas brillig in the bowtown’s hush,  
When fiddle rosin dust did chrumble bright;  
All strings were set to phizz and flush,  
And strumblat notes took furtive flight.  

Beware the Fiddler-Frawg, my dear,  
With rosin-sprayed claws and crooning sneer!  

He lurked beyond the varnished wood,  
Where shimmercrickets chirped at gloam;  
He snatched the bows in rosin-flood,  
And skewered the echoes of our home.  

And as in strumful thought he schemed,  
The bowman shook, his courage dreamed.  

One, two! One, two! And through and through,  
The bow did flash its silver crust;  
He smote the Frawg in rosin slough,  
Till naught remained but rosin dust—  
Hut! The fiddle chimed its final gust!  

And hast thou quelled the Fiddler-Frawg?  
O bowman brave, with heart unflawed!  

Come to my arms, my fiddle-lad!  
Oh, strum and let the strings rebound;  
The bowtown wakes with cheer so glad,  
Now rosin dust in legends crowned.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plane iron camber". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Plan-iron Camber

Twas brummish, and the glorty streams  
Did froodle o’er the plane;  
All mimmish crighters tumbled dreams  
In flick’ring, fabled bane.  

Beware the plane-iron camber, my son!  
Its iron ribs enthrave;  
Its forgelash and tixle shun  
All hardy hearts and brave.  

He grasped his scrimward gleamblade bright,  
Long blessed by eldritch seer;  
And lurched through bramble-snarl at night  
To hunt the forging fear.  

At clank of forge and molten sweep  
He met the hulking dread;  
One flashing slash did cleave its keep  
And stilled the roaring stead.  

Home trod he with his victory gleam  
Through amber dawn’s soft light;  
And kin and crones proclaimed the dream  
Of daring knight’s delight.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "orin bell hum". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Orin Bell Hum

’Twas the eve of the Orin Bell Hum,  
When borlish bumbles arose in strum;  
All crindlecrag lay wimbly and glum,  
Vexing the hush of the bramble-drum.  

Beware Snaggleflume with fangéd sneer,  
The hooty-hoot in the mangle-sphere;  
Grip thy quive-spear with heart austere,  
Till the Bell Hum rings crystal-clear.  

He ventured to fen with brash bristle-gleam,  
Murm’ring the chant of the shimmer-seam;  
Out sprang the beast by moonlight’s beam,  
When hum and hero became a team.  

Homeward he strode through bleak-thistle vale,  
All cobble-skinned with triumph hale;  
Kin hailed the Hum’s joyous tale,  
As echoes crowned dale, hill, and vale.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quenching brine hiss". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Quenching Brine Hiss

’Twas quench-chime brine, and the sly hiss rung  
Through drabmy dunes where sea-snails clung;  
All zarbled waves in stubbed delight  
Did flumber ’neath the foamy light.  

Beware the Quenching-Brine Hiss, O lad!  
Its clammy coils are grim and mad;  
Do not pursue its shivery roar,  
Lest murk and quaver seize your core.  

I snapt my glisker blade in hand  
And stalked the haunts of wet-white sand;  
One flit, two flit! Through splatch and spray  
I brived its fang and claimed the day.  

Then buzzled gulls and crabbled clans  
Chortled in briny braggart spans;  
Now peaceful laps the quenching brine—  
No hiss nor harm in briny tide.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "badger knot bloom". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Badgerknot Bloom

’Twas snibber and the gloaming dim,  
When badgerknots did bloom;  
The wimsy briar did quiver slim,  
And fringled scents perfume.

Beware the snatch of brumble-bloom,  
The fizzing, flortling sneer;  
Lest quompers snare your brabble-gloom  
And pin you fast in fear.

Yet bradle hearts of glimmer-gale  
Shall pluck that wondrous sprout;  
They’ll heed the bloom’s bewitching tale  
And rout the shadows out.

So join the jub of frisky forks,  
Where badgerknots entwine;  
Sing “Bloomish! Bloomish!” through the forks—  
The day is yours, divine!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nib tine micro‑mesh". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Ode to the Nib-Tine Micro-Mesh

All sliv’ry knarps in moon-bright glade,  
The nib-tine micro-mesh doth bide;  
Beware its flim-flam warp and braid,  
Lest glorpful step be mortified.  

It frimble-flutes with zindered hum,  
A chorpled lilt of fang and toe;  
It quavers when the wood-frots come,  
And frobs the snabbling gnorps below.  

Bold Brumblebeck, with gleaming spear,  
Did quest to breach the meshy snare;  
He twirled his flinter through the sphere,  
Yet felt its prickle, cold and bare.  

Now heed this twisted, tangled lay,  
Where nib-tine mesh doth slyly wait;  
Keep wit unwound, then haste away,  
Lest mirthful doom decide thy fate.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "krenovian plane throat". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Krenovian Plane Throat

’Twas brimmer in the krenovian glade,  
The slumphid moon on flintercoast played;  
All groons and glimlets warbled low  
Across the plane-throat’s spindling glow.

He seized his gleaming vorpal spar,  
And strode through gulch of fletch and bar;  
With heart aflump and eyebulb bright,  
He hunted on through gloaming night.

From quiv’ring bog and thrimmered fen  
There came a slayer of weary men;  
Its throat, a coil of strangling bone,  
Let raucous shrieks in nightwind drone.

“O plane-throat, bold and dread,” he cried,  
“Unhand the glimmernymph beside!  
I’ll smite your croonish fang and bite,  
And bring you to the dawn’s first light!”

With crackling rush and flindered roar,  
The plane-throat sprang on bracken floor;  
He swung the vorpal spar in flight—  
It sheared the beast in shimmered white.

Now brakens hush and glimbers gleam,  
The krenovian glade can dream;  
And wanderers whisper hushed and low  
Of how the plane-throat met its foe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "rain on a tin roof". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Glistlewhump on the Tinroof

’Twas drimpy eve on tinroof high,  
The gloaming glooth let drizzles fly;  
Each plink and plonk in bombly cheer  
Was chummed by night with sprightly sneer.  

Beware the glutter-splotch, my dear,  
That slurpeth forth in silver shear;  
Lest drabble-rime and spatter-gloom  
Should vex your tufted, cozy room.  

He snippled down the squeaky span,  
With muffled flump and whiffling pan;  
He hoisted helm of dripping cruse  
And tackled glists with hum and goose.  

O frabjous eve! Callooh, callay!  
The rainwhirls sing in gleamish spray;  
Then skedaddle, gloom-fritz, away!  
For tinroof’s tune is bright as day.

poem:
Sencha Kyusu Drip

Twas frumptious morn, and drifky leaves  
Did gyrgle-brim the teapot’s lip,  
All flimsy fronds in sliffling sieves  
Awaited Sencha Kyusu Drip.  

Beware the fizzly-sizzle sip,  
The snicker-snap of heated gleam!  
Beware the steamy, snortish nip  
That twirls and whirls the wakeful dream!  

He seized his whisk of cherry-wood  
And watched the bloopy bubbles swell;  
With gyreful stroke and fortitude  
He plunged the drip’s perfumed spell.  

One, two! One, two! And through and through  
The whisking wand went brazen-skid;  
He brewed the brew—and lo! he knew  
O frabjous cup! The Sencha Kyusu Drip!

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "split‑grade enlarger burn". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Split-Grade Enlarger Burn

1  
’Twas gloaming-tide, and the tintish slide  
Did slither from the brasty shroud;  
All flimsy were the crint-bound prints,  
And briller tiers stood proud.  

2  
Beware the Split-Grade Enlarger Burn,  
The hiss that scorches stout!  
Beware the lamp’s twofold twist,  
And shun the red-out bout!  

3  
He seized his tripod-sabre keen,  
Long time the slybul sought;  
And stood awhile in murkéd gloom  
Where drammish vapors wrought.  

4  
One scorching hiss! The filament  
Consumed the print so gay!  
He left it charred, and with a grin,  
He chortled on his way.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiridashi scribe line". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Kiridashi Scribe Line

’Twas brillig in the scribbled wood,  
The flindle-fronds their whispers swung;  
All mimsy were the lettered brood,  
And stummy slates were young.

Beware the kiridashi scribe line,  
The blade that carves in gleeful rhyme;  
Beware the quaffle-crust’d sign,  
And shun its griming chime!

He plunged his quill in snick’ring ink,  
And waited by the noddy tree;  
He heard the scrawling shadows slink,  
A scrimble-screeching spree.

Then forth it burst, the jagged mark—  
A beast of rune and jagged tone;  
Its claws inscribed the inky dark,  
Its eyes of glyphs were shown.

“O kiridashi, carve my word!”  
He cried, and swung with stony hand;  
The cutlass-verse in echoes heard,  
Fell swift upon the land.

The scribble-beast gave chortling shrieks,  
Its margins frayed in frabjous fray;  
Its rune-lined body shuddered, creaked,  
Then faded at display.

And now the wood is letter-clear,  
Where once confusion reigned in ink;  
All hail the scribe with blade so sheer—  
The kiridashi’s rightful brink!
